---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
Thanks!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7041158901/job/19163239218)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7041158901/job/19163239714)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7041158901/job/19163239522)

```suggestion
theorem card_edgeFinset_top_eq_card_choose_two :
```
Though maybe the naming is inconsistent in this area of mathlib, and @YaelDillies or @b-mehta knows better
I agree with your name, Eric.

I think we should rather have this lemma
```suggestion
    (⊤ : SimpleGraph V).edgeFinset = {e | ¬ e.IsDiag} := by
```

Surely you mean
```suggestion
    (⊤ : SimpleGraph V).edgeFinset = Finset.univ.filter fun e => ¬e.IsDiag := by
```
Done (for both variations).
I would hope the proof now follows in terms of some general lemma about the cardinality of `Sym2`
Done.
If you do induction on `f`, aesop should be able to handle it.
This is clearly impossible. `f`'s type is `Sym2 V` which is not an inductive type.
Do you know about [`Quotient.inductionOn`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Init/Core.html#Quotient.inductionOn)?
Yeah, now everything works.

```suggestion
open Finset
open scoped BigOperators
```
Why this change? A priori you're making the lemma strictly less general.
It's redundant – everything still compiles _without_ it. So the following lemmas cannot have been made less general by the removal of this variable.
That's not necessarily true, unfortunately; though certainly I would have expected a docstring explaining whether this is intentional.
@kmill, what's your opinion here?

@Parcly-Taxel The rule of thumb with Fintype and Decidable instances is that you want to be sure that you have every instance be its own argument, even if that means redundancy. That's to help with all the overlapping instances we tend to have with these classes (especially since sometimes it's intentional, for example with `classical` and `Decidable`).

However -- Lean 4 doesn't seem to play as well with overlapping instances as in Lean 3 (it wants to resynthesize every instance from scratch, but Lean 3 was happy to use instances it picked up from unification), so this rule of thumb seems like it needs tweaking. It sounds plausible to me that if one `[...]` argument can be derived from the others, then there's no difference between including it or excluding it, so excluding it makes sense.

If we care about maximal rewritability, then we should be using `{...}` arguments for instances that can be picked up from unification. That's not great, though, because that tends to mean you need two versions of rewrite lemmas, since different instances tend to be picked up in the forwards and backwards directions. I wonder if we can convince core Lean to add "`[{...}]`" arguments that give us the Lean 3 behavior? (Edit: [started Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/270676-lean4/topic/Mini-RFC.3A.20Weak.20instance.20arguments/near/404449998))

In short, ideally we'd have the extra `Fintype (Sym2 V)` argument for smoother rewriting, but at the moment I'm not sure it actually does that. I could be wrong though.
Let's not remove it for the moment then. It'll be much harder to find which lemmas could be generalised by having redundant arguments if those lemmas do not already have those arguments.

That seems reasonable to me.

To give a concrete issue that having an extra argument is meant to solve: you can obtain a `Fintype (Sym2 V)` instance from both [`Sym2.instFintype`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Finset/Sym.html#Sym2.instFintype) and [`Quotient.fintype`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Fintype/Basic.html#Quotient.fintype)
Reverted.

We could factor out the Sym2 part
```
-- put right after Sym2.fromRel_top
theorem fromRel_ne :
    fromRel (fun (x y : α) z => z.symm : Symmetric Ne) = {z | ¬ IsDiag z} := by
  ext z
  exact z.ind (by simp)
```
and then the theorem is
```
theorem edgeSet_top : (⊤ : SimpleGraph V).edgeSet = {e | ¬e.IsDiag} :=
  Sym2.fromRel_ne
```
I'd prefer that we re-use the previous theorem rather than dig into an `ext` proof. This works to do that: `rw [← coe_inj]; simp`

Could you switch this to `simp_rw` so it's clear that it's a sequence of rewrites?
```suggestion
  simp_rw [Set.toFinset_card, edgeSet_top, Set.coe_setOf, ← Sym2.card_subtype_not_diag]
```
(It could be `rw` if only `edgeSet_top` didn't give "motive not type correct")

Could you add this additional theorem here?
```
@[simp]
theorem edgeSet_subset_setOf_not_isDiag : G.edgeSet ⊆ {e | ¬e.IsDiag} :=
  fun _ h => (Sym2.fromRel_irreflexive (sym := G.symm)).mp G.loopless h
```

Here's a more conceptual proof. (I golfed this from a few `apply`s that show the steps better, but at least you can see the expected types in the info view to follow along).
```suggestion
  rw [← card_edgeFinset_top_eq_card_choose_two]
  exact card_le_of_subset (edgeFinset_mono le_top)
```
Done.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: number of edges in a complete graph
